hints_html:
How could you possibly use the fact that \(\displaystyle f'(3)=5\) to solve this limit?

Is there any way to use the definition of the derivative?
hints_latex:
How could you possibly use the fact that $\displaystyle f'(3)=5$ to
solve this limit?
Is there any way to use the definition of the derivative?
hints_raw:
How could you possibly use the fact that <math>\displaystyle f'(3)=5 </math> to solve this limit?
Is there any way to use the definition of the derivative?
question: 1 (e)
sols_html:
First of all, both the numerator and denominator converge to zero as \(x\to3\), so we cannot solve the limit directly.

Instead, we need to make use of the fact that \(\displaystyle f'(3)=5\). Taking this as a hint, let’s recall the definition of the derivative as the limit of a difference quotient:

\[\begin{aligned} f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a}\end{aligned}\]

For us, a = 3 and \(\displaystyle f'(3) = 5\), so we know the left hand side of the equation above. To find the limit of the quotient we are given, let us rewrite our quotient in a similar form as the difference quotient:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{x^2-3x}{f(3)-f(x)} &= x \frac{x-3}{f(3)-f(x)} \\ &= x \left(\frac{f(3)-f(x)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\ &= x \left(\frac{(-1)(f(x)-f(3))}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\ &= x(-1)^{-1} \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\ &= -x \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1}\end{aligned}\]

We now recognize the second term as the difference quotient. Hence, applying the limit laws, we arrive at our final answer

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x\to3} \frac{x^2-3x}{f(3)-f(x)} &= \lim_{x\to3} \left[-x \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1}\right] \\ &= -\left(\lim_{x\to3}x\right) \left(\lim_{x\to3} \frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\ &= -3 \left(f'(3)\right)^{-1} \\ &=-3 \left(5\right)^{-1} \\ &=-\frac35\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
First of all, both the numerator and denominator converge to zero as
$x\to3$, so we cannot solve the limit directly.

Instead, we need to make use of the fact that $\displaystyle f'(3)=5$.
Taking this as a hint, let's recall the definition of the derivative as
the limit of a difference quotient:

\begin{align*}
f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a}
\end{align*}

For us, \emph{a = 3} and $\displaystyle f'(3) = 5$, so we know the left
hand side of the equation above. To find the limit of the quotient we
are given, let us rewrite our quotient in a similar form as the
difference quotient:

\begin{align*}
\frac{x^2-3x}{f(3)-f(x)} &=  x \frac{x-3}{f(3)-f(x)} \\
&= x \left(\frac{f(3)-f(x)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= x \left(\frac{(-1)(f(x)-f(3))}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= x(-1)^{-1} \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= -x \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1}
\end{align*}

We now recognize the second term as the difference quotient. Hence,
applying the limit laws, we arrive at our final answer

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x\to3} \frac{x^2-3x}{f(3)-f(x)} &= \lim_{x\to3} \left[-x \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1}\right] \\
&= -\left(\lim_{x\to3}x\right) \left(\lim_{x\to3} \frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= -3 \left(f'(3)\right)^{-1} \\
&=-3 \left(5\right)^{-1} \\
&=-\frac35
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
First of all, both the numerator and denominator converge to zero as <math>x\to3</math>, so we cannot solve the limit directly.

Instead, we need to make use of the fact that <math>\displaystyle f'(3)=5</math>. Taking this as a hint, let's recall the definition of the derivative as the limit of a difference quotient:

:<math>
f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a}
</math>

For us, ''a = 3'' and <math>\displaystyle f'(3) = 5</math>, so we know the left hand side of the equation above. To find the limit of the quotient we are given, let us rewrite our quotient in a similar form as the difference quotient:

:<math>\begin{align}
\frac{x^2-3x}{f(3)-f(x)} &=  x \frac{x-3}{f(3)-f(x)} \\
&= x \left(\frac{f(3)-f(x)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= x \left(\frac{(-1)(f(x)-f(3))}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= x(-1)^{-1} \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= -x \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1}
\end{align}</math>

We now recognize the second term as the difference quotient. Hence, applying the limit laws, we arrive at our final answer
:<math> \begin{align}
\lim_{x\to3} \frac{x^2-3x}{f(3)-f(x)} &= \lim_{x\to3} \left[-x \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1}\right] \\
&= -\left(\lim_{x\to3}x\right) \left(\lim_{x\to3} \frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= -3 \left(f'(3)\right)^{-1} \\
&=-3 \left(5\right)^{-1} \\
&=-\frac35
\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
If a function y=f(x) is differentiable at x=3 and \(\displaystyle {}f'(3)=5\), find the limit

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x\to{3}}\frac{x^2-3x}{f(3)-f(x)}\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
If a function y=f(x) is differentiable at x=3 and <math>\displaystyle{}f'(3)=5</math>, find the limit

:<math>
\lim_{x\to{3}}\frac{x^2-3x}{f(3)-f(x)}
</math>
